qas.question: What is another word for a thin definition?
What is another word for a thick definition?
Who commonly, or at least attempt to, abide by the rule of law?
On what do aspects of the rule of law do formalist definitions focus?
What is the third and lesser referred to approach on defining the rule of law?
Who has spoken against the rule of law?
Who uses a substantive or thin definition of rule of law?
Who uses a formalist or thick definition of rule of law?
What definition by formalist makes a judgment about the justness of law?
What conception of the rule of law excludes substantive rights?

context: Despite wide use by <a2_0><b5_0>politicians, judges and academics<b5_0/><a2_0/>, the rule of law has been described as "an exceedingly elusive notion". Among modern <b6_0><b7_0>legal theorists<b7_0/>,<b6_0/> one finds that at least two principal conceptions of the rule of law can be identified: a <a0_0>formalist<a0_0/> or "thin" definition, and a <a1_0>substantive<a1_0/> or "thick" definition; one occasionally encounters a third "<a4_0>functional<a4_0/>" conception. Formalist definitions of <b8_0>the rule of law<b8_0/> do not make a judgment about the "justness" of law itself, but define <a3_0>specific procedural attributes<a3_0/> that a legal framework must have in order to be in compliance with the rule of law. <b9_0>Substantive conceptions<b9_0/> of the rule of law go beyond this and include certain substantive rights that are said to be based on, or derived from, the rule of law.
